issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: This issue has been validated/reproduced, but has not been prioritized yet.
status.name: Confirmed

fields.description:
User can registered images like this:
{code}
IMAGE	emi-8ee96f1b	981452756172/normal	981452756172	available	private	x86_64	machine				ebs	hvm	
BLOCKDEVICEMAPPING	EBS	/dev/sdc	snap-431a6b5b	3	true		
BLOCKDEVICEMAPPING	EPHEMERAL	/dev/sde	ephemeral0
BLOCKDEVICEMAPPING	EBS	/dev/sda	snap-635a0e96	3	true
{code}
After instance started meta-data replies with information provided by user 
{code}
ubuntu@euca-1-110-101-233:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/root; echo
/dev/sda
ubuntu@euca-1-110-101-233:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0; echo
sde
ubuntu@euca-1-110-101-233:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ebs1; echo
sdc
{code}
but in reality on the instance
{code}
root (ebs) is /dev/sda
ebs1 is /dev/sdb
ephemeral0 is /dev/sdc
{code}

Applications might think that by writing to sdc they are writing to EBS but it is actually an ephemeral device.
fields.summary: Consistent disk serial IDs (was: report real device names in meta-data)

comments.body:
[~vasya], could you check what the relevant section of {{instance-libvirt.xml}} looks like? For example, for one instance I am seeing:

{code}
    <disk device="disk" type="block">
      <driver cache="none"/>
      <source dev="/disk1/storage/eucalyptus/instances/work/AIDHXAYKYRDKBDX9DMOY6/i-9ccce238/link-to-sda"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
    <disk device="disk" type="block">
      <driver cache="none"/>
      <source dev="/disk1/storage/eucalyptus/instances/work/AIDHXAYKYRDKBDX9DMOY6/i-9ccce238/link-to-sdb"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vdb"/>
    </disk>
{code}

I suspect we specify the correct {{dev}}, but that the guest OS selects device names that are named contiguously as it allocates them. We do not guarantee that device names requested for dynamically attached volumes are correct. With some tricks -- i.e., temporarily attaching dummy devices -- we can try to ensure they are correct for devices attached at boot-time. Although that feels hack-y.

If we do not, it would be appropriate to return correct device names via meta-data, but I am not sure if there is a reliable way to discover that information from the guest.

[~dmitrii], you are correct. System provides valid names for disks. For the instance described above the {{instance-libvirt.xml}} looks like:
{code}
    <disk device="disk" type="block">
      <driver cache="none"/>
      <source dev="/dev/disk/by-id/scsi-1IET_00060001"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
    <disk device="disk" type="block">
      <driver cache="none"/>
      <source dev="/dev/disk/by-id/scsi-1IET_00070001"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vdc"/>
    </disk>
    <disk device="disk" type="block">
      <driver cache="none"/>
      <source dev="/disk1/storage/eucalyptus/instances/work/AIDXYDKUCGMEFYAYMB7PI/i-ea1c6234/link-to-sde"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vde"/>
    </disk>
{code}

Yeah, I thought about playing the game of dummy devices, but it's fraught with danger: older Linux kernels are less predictable in name assignments, the approach won't work for dynamic attachments, and device names won't survive reboots. I think we should just accept that on KVM (and VMware) we don't have control over names and don't have a good way to discover the real names from outside the guest. This means that:

* names requested in BDMs or in volume attach requests may not be respected
* names returned by the metadata service may not be correct

Given that, I think we should offer an alternative method to match up device names with entries in BDM and with volume IDs. We already have such a mechanism for dynamic volumes, actually, and I would propose that we review it and extend it to BDM-specified devices, as well. Currently, volume ID and the requested device name are embedded into the disk's serial number as follows:

{code}
# cat /sys/block/vdc/serial
vol-b27c814c-dev-sdz
{code}

The device is also accessible via a sym-link:

{code}
# ls /dev/disk/by-id/virtio-*
/dev/disk/by-id/virtio-vol-b27c814c-dev-sdz
{code}

I think that adding a {{euca-}} prefix may be a good way to flag it as a eucalyptus-specific feature. And BDM-specified devices can be supported using the names used by the metadata service (root, ephemeral0, ebs1, etc.). Keeping the requested name in the serial device offers an alternative way to correlate user's request with the actual device. Thus, serial numbers would look like:

{code}
euca-root-dev-sda
euca-ephemeral0-dev-sdc
euca-ebs1-dev-sdb
euca-vol-XYZ123-dev-sdf
{code}

or maybe

{code}
euca-bdm-root-dev-sda
euca-bdm-ephemeral0-dev-sdc
euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-sdb
euca-vol-XYZ123-dev-sdf
{code}
Discussion in the euca-users list about the topic https://groups.google.com/a/eucalyptus.com/forum/#!msg/euca-users/n56rKyDB6X4/f3YVWKo3DyoJ
Setting id for all device can part of 4.1

Implementation for *4.1*: given that reporting accurate OS-specific disk device names in instance metadata cannot be done accurately on KVM, the solution ultimately implemented for this ticket involves setting disk serial IDs using a consistent pattern, with *requested* device name as part of it:

{code}
euca-bdm-ebsN-dev-NAME
euca-bdm-ephemeralN-dev-NAME
euca-vol-XXXXX-dev-NAME
{code}

Thus, a user can identify the correct disk inside the instance by looking for the *requested* device name (either in block-device mappings used by 'RunInstance' or as a parameter to 'AttachVolume' request) among the serial IDs of disks available on the system.
[~dmitrii] What is the best way to verify this issue.

[~mmunn1], I'd run an instance with -b parameter with at least one DBM and attach a disk to it. After that ssh to the instance and 'ls -la /dev/disk/ | grep euca'. The list should have paths that you requested. I'd also verify that disk sized at correct.

Yes, [~vasya] is right: an instance with an extra block-device mapping and an extra volume attached after it was started pretty much covers all the cases. Directory {{/dev/disk/by-id/}} should list the IDs. They should also be accessible inside files that match the pattern {{/sys/block/*/serial}}.

{code}
[b-16:~/mike]euca-run-instances -b /dev/sdc=ephemeral0 emi-a99f835f -k mmunn
RESERVATION	r-0d2f088a	793112121268	default
INSTANCE	i-cd1c82f3	emi-a99f835f			pending	mmunn	0		m1.small	2015-01-22T21:19:33.526Z	PARTI00				monitoring-disabled	0.0.0.0	0.0.0.0			ebs					hvm			sg-6e86668f		

ubuntu@euca-172-18-96-203:/dev/disk$ ls -l by-id
total 0
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root  9 Jan 22 13:20 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-vd -> ../../vda
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 10 Jan 22 13:20 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-vd-part1 -> ../../vda1
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root  9 Jan 22 13:20 virtio-euca-bdm-ephemeral0- -> ../../vdb
{code}

[~dmitrii], should virtio-euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-vd be virtio-euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-vda? Does code truncate last char somewhere? Also root disk is not reported in meta-data as ebs1. Only disks that are created as start up time, excluding root, are reported as ebsX. I am afraid that the fix is not suitable for all case. In the case of the instance started with something like this:
{code}
euca-run-instances emi-54a39473 -k vk -b /dev/sdc=snap-6562a62e -b /dev/sde=snap-f8d7e7cf
{code}
Meta-data is
{code}
curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/
ami
ebs1
ebs2
emi
root
{code}
and IDs are reported like this
{code}
ubuntu@euca-1-101-98-154:~$ ls -la /dev/disk/by-id
total 0
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 160 Jan 22 13:51 .
drwxr-xr-x 6 root root 120 Jan 22 13:51 ..
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root   9 Jan 22 13:51 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-vd -> ../../vda
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root  10 Jan 22 13:51 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs1-dev-vd-part1 -> ../../vda1
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root   9 Jan 22 13:51 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs2-dev-vd -> ../../vdb
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root  10 Jan 22 13:51 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs2-dev-vd-part1 -> ../../vdb1
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root   9 Jan 22 13:51 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs3-dev-vd -> ../../vdc
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root  10 Jan 22 13:51 virtio-euca-bdm-ebs3-dev-vd-part1 -> ../../vdc1
{code}

I am afraid [~vasya] is right:

* root disk should not be reported as ebs1
* the device name isn't correct (it should be 'scd', not 'vd')

I guess we'll have to kick this one out :-(
